title: Civil Servant Exchange Program (CSEP)
objective:
As European students and future civil servants, we believe that exchanges should not stop once studies come to an end.
               




                We therefore propose the creation of a Civil Servant Exchange Program (CSEP), an exchange and training programme between civil servants of the Member States of the European Union. The aim of this ‘Erasmus for the civil service’ would be to offer civil servants from EU Member States professional experience in a similar service in another Member State for a period of 2 to 12 months. During the exchange, civil servants could continue to receive the salary of their home country, subject to compensation from the EU if this salary is lower than that received in the host country for an equivalent position.
               

                The CSEP would strengthen the freedom of movement of workers in the EU, foster an exchange of best practices between civil services and improve links between Member States. In addition, the CSEP would help civil servants to overcome the numerous challenges they encounter in their working relations with t
annex: The EU is also a union of European peoples and we believe that it should be lived first-hand by more people. We would like the workers who play a key role in its Member States, i.e. civil servants (teachers, hospital staff, prison staff, judges, police officers, administrative staff, etc.), to also benefit from the European experience through this programme. The Civil Servant Exchange Program would offer the EU and its Member States several benefits: 1. Benefits of a European experience The aim of the programme is to enable all civil servants, irrespective of their place in the hierarchy or their field of activity, to reap the benefits of a European experience. The establishment of a European exchange framework for national civil servants would give them the opportunity to meet their European counterparts and experience life abroad. We believe that such an exchange would forge links between Europeans and thus foster mutual understanding. It would also be an opportunity for them to travel, discover new cultures and have intense and enriching experiences. Career progression in the civil service does not always allow for professional experience abroad, unlike for private-sector employees. Thanks to the CESP, the civil service will be able to offer European experiences to its civil servants, which will improve their autonomy and adaptability. This would make employment in the civil service more appealing. 2. Development of additional skills and exchange of best practices The exchange will enable civil servants to practise foreign languages, develop skills in an international environment and learn other forms of public management. Above all, it will be an opportunity for civil servants to exchange current practices from their national civil service and learn new ones. They will then be able to use the practices learned during the exchange back in their home country. These practices may include new forms of administrative or healthcare organisation, or a particular teaching method for civil servants working in the field of national education. In addition, this programme will provide an opportunity for civil servants to see the impact of different public responses to issues that are common to many national civil services. While exchanges and the coordination of best practices are encouraged in the EU through the Open Method of Coordination, the CSEP will allow civil servants to directly try out and exchange best practices on the ground, thus establishing a ‘direct method of coordination’ through long-term practice. 3. Strengthening the EU and its Member States As we are determined to pursue the project of an 'ever closer union’ among the peoples of Europe, we propose the establishment of the CSEP to strengthen the link between national civil services and citizens. We believe that the more citizens are able to move within the EU, the better they understand the different countries that make up the EU. The civil service is one of the biggest sectors of employment in each Member State. However, it offers few opportunities to work in an international environment. We want to develop contacts between workers who are involved in running the Member States, so that they can also benefit from a European experience. Thanks to the programme, a whole category of workers will be able to move within the EU. Thus, the establishment of the CSEP will help improve the functioning of the internal market and strengthen freedom of movement for workers. The programme will also enhance decision-making at European level through exchanges between civil services and make it easier for them to cooperate with each other, thus enabling them to better identify common problems. Since any decision by one Member State inevitably affects the others, national administrations must become better acquainted and understand each other to ensure that they share the same values and are thus able to run their countries together democratically. We believe that bringing national administrations closer will undoubtedly facilitate European decision-making. The CSEP is a further step towards a Europe that shares and promotes common values. Establishment of the CSEP by the European Union and its Member States: The role of the EU in establishing the CSEP will be to develop a common European legislative framework. It will allow Member States to freely and voluntarily offer positions in their civil service for civil servants on exchange. In accordance with the principle of subsidiarity and the respective competences of the EU and its Member States, national administrations may limit access to this programme to certain positions in order to maintain public order and safeguard the security of important national public information. As regards the remuneration of civil servants, we are in favour of the idea that, during the exchange, civil servants will continue to receive their salary from their home country. An EU compensation mechanism should be provided for in cases where the salary received by civil servants on exchange is lower than that received in the host country for an equivalent position. The European Social Fund could be the institution responsible for offsetting differences in salaries (Article 3(1)(a)(vii) of Regulation (EU) No 1304/2013). Additional financial support from the EU or Member States may be considered depending on the specific situation.

title: Green Garden Roof Tops
objective: In Europe there are many existing stores with an empty rooftop; in most of the cases these rooftops are not being used for any specific purpose. In addition, these rooftops are full of plastic and stones, materials of which the roof is made of. Therefore, these areas are in itself not contributing to the benefits of the environment, rather they are simply increasing the environmental damages. The reason of focusing on the environmental benefits, is stemming from our current time environmental crisis. We need to rethink and find ways to increase the awareness of environmental problems and how to bring our society, the economy and the protection of our planet in a healthy balance. Therefore, the core of the plan is to utilize the existing spaces found on rooftops.  The idea is to create on different corporations’ rooftops a green garden area. In this way the unutilized roofs, could be transformed in means able of improving and aiding the environmental crisis.

title: Ban Fossil Fuel Advertising and Sponsorships
objective: We call on the European Commission to propose an EU legislative act: prohibiting advertisements for fossil fuels, as well as air, road and water-borne transportation (other than transport services of general economic interest) powered by fossil fuels; prohibiting advertisements  from any undertakings active in the market for fossil fuels, in particular by extracting, refining, supplying, distributing or selling fossil fuels; prohibiting sponsorships by undertakings defined under point 2 above, or using trademarks or commercial names used for fossil fuels. This law would fall into the EU competence, in that it would consist in an internal market regulation aimed at enhancing consumer protection, as well as a high level of public health and environmental protection. Indeed, this legislation would increase public awareness of products and technologies that are responsible for climate change and other environmental and health harms. As such, it would pursue objectives that are envisaged by the EU environmental and consumer protection policies, via the harmonisation of rules on fossil fue
annex: Our European Citizens’ Initiative (ECI) aims to achieve a ban on any fossil fuel advertising or sponsorship. Specifically, our ECI calls on the Europe Commission to propose to members states: A ban on any promotion or advertising, direct or indirect, as well as any free or promotional distribution, or any sponsorship relationship: a.   for any and all companies and associated sub brands or lobbying organisations that extract, refine, produce, supply, distribute, or sell any fossil fuels b.   for any companies that promote the use of any fossil fuel powered air, road or maritime vehicles operating from fossil fuels, with the exception of vehicles dedicated to transport services of general economic interest c.   of any fossil fuel products including oil, fossil gas, and coal This would include a ban of the above products and companies ability to advertise and sponsor in the following areas: ●   Offline: any advertisements in print media, television, billboard, radio, SRI, or academic publications ●   Online: any social media ads or branded content on all social or traditional media platforms ●   Sport- any sponsorship of sports clubs or events ●   Culture- any sponsorship of museums, arts institutions, theatres, music venues, festivals, events or artists ●   Education- public universities, schools, or any public educational institution ●   Science: any public science festivals or funding for public scientific institutes and educational publications ●   Public events- in particular related to climate, health, biodiversity, environment and ecological sustainability. ●   Third party media events Why? 1.   Fossil fuels are perpetuating the climate crisis, and should not be advertised The advertisement of climate damaging products and intentional subsequent uplift in sales has a negative impact on an increase of greenhouse gas emissions which we cannot afford. For example, the New Weather Institute think tank found in a case study into a singular Audi advertising campaign, there was an uplift of sales driven by the advertising of up to 132,700 cars, which multiplied with the carbon footprint sold per item resulted in an overall increase of greenhouse gas emissions of 5,175,300 tonnes of carbon dioxide (CO2) equivalent due to  a singular advertising campaign. 2.   Fossil fuels have created a public health crisis, and should not be advertised Air pollution is currently killing more people than smoking  and most of the particulate matter and other air pollutants in Europe come from the burning of fossil fuels. When fossil fuels are killing people via air pollution and other means, why is it still socially acceptable or legal to have the same brands responsible for sponsoring our public institutions, and having access to our advertising spaces? If tobacco advertising and sponsorship are banned on the basis of public health, then why are we not aiming for a European wide ban on fossil fuel advertising and sponsorships much like the EU tobacco advertising and sponsorship ban of 2003/4. 3.   Fossil fuel companies are misleading consumers, and some have been found to be breaking advertising guidelines. Some fossil fuel companies are being legally challenged for their advertisements because their advertising campaigns tend to overemphasize renewable products and misrepresent their actual investment into renewable technologies. For example last year ClientEarth filed a legal complaint using OECD guidelines against BP for misleading consumers into thinking they were a renewables company, when they in fact spend 96% of their total investment on oil and gas. In legal terms many of these advertisements could be challenged, but the EU should be taking proactive steps to remove this threat preemptively by creating legislation to prevent this. 4.   Fossil fuel sponsorships are being used for political access In 2016  this Unearthed investigation found that BP used their sponsorship deal with the British Museum and a specific 'Day of the Dead' exhibition to further their oil plans in Mexico and Australia. FOI requests revealed that BP sought to access Mexican and UK government figures at a private event by the British Museum as part of the BP-sponsored Days of the Dead festival, just one month before bidding opened for new deepwater drilling permits controlled by the Mexican government. There are multiple examples of fossil fuel companies using these sponsorships to advance their own business via the granted access of sponsorships.

title: European EcoScore
objective:
We are a citizens’ movement driven by young people from all over Europe who want to take concrete action for our environment!
               
               In view of the ambitions of the Green Deal for Europe and the Paris Agreement, we call on the European Commission to impose a reliable "European EcoScore". It consists of a label providing European consumers with transparent information about the environmental impact of products manufactured or sold on the European Union market.
               
               This compulsory and clearly visible indication on the packaging would provide simple and reliable information on the environmental impact of the product according to the letter selected (“A” = very environmentally friendly, while "F" = very harmful to the environment).
               

               Objectives:
               
               • To enable European consumers to make informed choices that take into account the environmental impact of the products on offer, based on a clear and reliable indication.
               
               • To encourage professionals to r
annex: Our project in a nutshell: We lead a European citizens' initiative that aims to introduce a European EcoScore, i.e. an indication of the environmental impact of products manufactured and sold on the European market. The EcoScore would be indicated visually on the product packaging in the main field of vision, to bring more transparency on the environmental impact of those products. Our highest ambition is to have it displayed on all types of products. However, we are conscious that at the present time it is difficult to calculate it for complex products. Therefore, we consider that developing it primarily on food and clothe items is a good start! Current observations: • The European Union is taking proactive measures aimed at combating climate change (Green Deal and Climate Law). It is essential to support it and to move from declarations to action! • An increasing number of consumers want clear and transparent information about the products they buy. The success of applications such as Yuka,  which indicates the nutritional quality of food products (more than 20 million downloads), or the launch of similar labels - reporting the environmental impact of products - by different supermarkets or other applications (as Open-Food-Fact, Etiquettable, Eco-Score collective, …) indicates that such demand for information is growing. • The eco-score concept is developing. However, initiatives are private, which has several drawbacks: o There is no legal harmonization of the calculation methods of the different eco-scores. o The eco-scores’ initiators do not have all information needed to calculate the eco-score, as they depend on the goodwill of producers and companies. o Until now, most eco-scores developed are not directly indicated on the products but are only accessible through a scan from a specific application. How does our proposal respond to the observations made? • Our initiative contributes to the necessary awareness-raising of European consumers about the environmental impact of the products they buy, by providing them with a clear, reliable and transparent indication. • We are sending a clear signal to the European institutions about the importance of implementing measures that benefit the environment. • A European EcoScore helps to encourage professionals to reduce their environmental impact while highlighting products that are already environmentally friendly. • A European EcoScore offers a uniform indication based on an identical calculation process for the whole territory of the European Union, avoiding confusion for the consumer. • With the introduction of this mandatory official indication, professionals have to provide all the necessary information to calculate the European EcoScore. • Our initiative is federative: in these times of pandemic, young people in particular are looking for projects which bind them and allow them to feel involved in their future. Our ambition is to create a collective and proactive movement that affirms we are "United in diversity" and that transcends generations! How to determine the European EcoScore? This is a complex issue that needs to be discussed by experts. Let us recall that the purpose of a European Citizens' Initiative is to propose an idea to the European Commission, which can then take it into consideration and implement it concretely. Nevertheless, we have several suggestions. Firstly, it is useful to remind that several ‘eco-score’ proposed by private initiatives are already in use. There are therefore various databases (see Agribalyse) and methods that could reasonably be used to calculate such a score. The European EcoScore could be inspired by these actions. For instance, a system of bonus/malus points could be added to the calculation method to favour certain desirable characteristics of a product. Amongst other things, we think about the local and/or seasonal aspect of it, its impact on soils and water quality, the animal welfare, the award of the European organic farming label, ... Secondly, we believe that it would be interesting to use the product’s life cycle assessment (LCA method) - developed by the European Commission for more than 10 years - to calculate the European EcoScore. The LCA method is taking into accounts many important criteria needed to calculated the EcoScore, such as the extraction, transportation, packaging, utilization, etc. of the products. However, this scientific method is subject to criticism: to be applied to a large scale of products, it must be developed and simplified. We insist on the fact that the European EcoScore calculation method should be based on scientific evidence. As foreseen in the European treaties (article 114, §3 TFEU), the European Commission's proposals must take into account any new developments based on scientific facts. The method for determining the European EcoScore will thus have to evolve in line with new scientific knowledge and the upward evolution of minimum environmental standards. Additional request: We believe that detailed information about the European EcoScore of each product should be made easily available to consumers. We propose that a barcode on the product can be scanned directly to take the consumer to an online platform. This page would include an explanation of the European EcoScore calculation process, a reference to other labels obtained by the product (and recognised by the European Union), as well as details of the score obtained for each criteria.

title: SAVE CRUELTY FREE COSMETICS - COMMIT TO A EUROPE WITHOUT ANIMAL TESTING
objective:
With the EU ban on cosmetics tests on animals came the promise of a Europe in which animals no longer suffer and die for the sake of cosmetics. That promise has been broken. Authorities still demand animal tests on ingredients used in cosmetics, which goes against the expectations and wishes of the public and the intention of legislators.
               




                Yet, never have we had such powerful non-animal tools for assuring safety or such a golden opportunity to revolutionise human and environmental protection. The European Commission must uphold and strengthen the ban and transition to animal-free safety assessment.
               



                We call on the European Commission to do the following:
               



                1. Protect and strengthen the cosmetics animal testing ban.
               

                Initiate legislative change to achieve consumer, worker, and environmental protection for all cosmetics ingredients without testing on animals for any purpose at any time.
               



                2. Transform EU chemicals regulat
annex: The World-Leading EU Cosmetics Animal Testing and Marketing Bans We call on the European Commission to protect and strengthen the cosmetics animal testing ban. The wishes of citizens and legislators are clear: animals must not suffer and die for the sake of cosmetics. We maintain that new safety assessments for cosmetics ingredients imported into, manufactured in, or sold within the EU may only rely on non-animal data. As such, EU test requirements – including requirements set out in REACH – must not undermine the bans. Instead, a substance-tailored approach should be applied to ensure consumers, workers, and the environment are protected without further tests on animals. It is essential that the European Commission ensure proper implementation of the bans on animal testing for cosmetics and on marketing animal-tested products as originally intended and instigate legislative change to achieve this goal for both human health and environmental toxicity endpoints across all relevant sectors. To achieve the objective of protecting and strengthening the cosmetics animal testing ban, we urge the European Commission to ensure that the following mandates are met: • Immediately implement the existing EU bans on animal testing for cosmetics and the marketing of ingredients tested on animals as intended by legislators to ensure that only non-animal methods are used for the safety assessment of cosmetics ingredients. • Clarify that the requirement to rely on non-animal data for the safety assessment of cosmetics ingredients must be applied and animal data rejected, regardless of the location and purpose of animal tests conducted after the cut-off periods described in Article 18(2) of the EU Cosmetics Regulation. • Initiate legislation to strengthen and broaden the cosmetics testing bans to ensure that consumers, workers, and the environment are protected without new tests on animals. • Devise a robust testing strategy for cosmetics ingredients using only available non-animal assessment strategies so that the implementation of the Chemicals Strategy for Sustainability reflects the overwhelming support for strengthening – rather than weakening – the protection of animals in Europe. Transforming Chemicals Regulation We call on the European Commission to transform EU chemicals regulation. The European Green Deal introduces a worthy commitment to a toxic-free environment whilst also presenting a golden opportunity for modern and sustainable regulation of chemicals. With the right investment and careful design, the EU could use non-animal approaches to provide the best protection of human health and the environment without wasting resources on an over-burdened and unreliable system dependent on the suffering and death of animals. To achieve the objective of ensuring sustainable chemicals regulation with recourse to additional animal test requirements, we urge the Commission to ensure that, at a minimum, the following mandates are met: • Put in place concrete steps – with dedicated funding, ambitious timelines and cross-sectoral support – to develop, validate, and implement human-relevant, non-animal approaches to identifying toxic chemicals. • Ensure that the rapid uptake of non-animal New Approach Methodologies is aligned between the European agencies with administrative responsibility for chemicals, biocides, plant protection products, pharmaceuticals, and other products. • Ensure that test requirement deadlines are not applied at the expense of scientific rigour or human and environmental safety by allowing a default fallback to reliance on unreliable tests on animals. Modernising Science in the EU We call on the European Commission to modernise science in the EU. The EU is at a crossroads. Decision-makers can choose either to continue relying on archaic animal tests or to lead the world by fostering a new era of animal-free science. Seventy-two per cent of adults in EU member states agree  that the time is right for the EU to plot a roadmap – containing concrete, measurable targets with associated timelines – towards its final goal of ending animal tests. To achieve the objective of working towards a roadmap for the phase-out of all animal testing in the EU, we urge the Commission to ensure that, at a minimum, the following mandates are met: • Openly endorse the desirability of phasing out the use of animals in science and state the belief that this is achievable. To illustrate this commitment, prioritise a transition to non-animal approaches as an integral part of all EU research, innovation, and education initiatives, while also acknowledging that Directive 2010/63/EU does not in and of itself represent a roadmap towards full replacement. • Prioritise the development and validation of non-animal methods in the EU budget and new overarching policies such as the European Green Deal, the Chemicals Strategy for Sustainability, and post-COVID recovery plans and redirect funding away from animal studies to alternatives. • Coordinate actions across the directorates-general and agencies responsible for aspects of research, regulatory testing, education, and funding with the involvement of all member states to achieve a strategic focus on the final goal of fully replacing the use of animals in scientific procedures. • Include in the legislative proposal ambitious and achievable science-based targets with regard to a reduction in numbers of animals used, investments in advanced non-animal models and infrastructures, education and training synergy, and regulatory acceptance of non-animal methods.

title: ReturnthePlastics: A Citizen’s Initiative to implement an EU-wide deposit-system to recycle plastic bottles
objective: With the #ReturnthePlastics European Citizen's Initiative, we request the European Commission: 1. To implement an EU-wide deposit-system to recycle plastic bottles 2. To incentivize all EU Member states that supermarkets (chains) which are selling plastic bottles to install reverse vending machines for recycling the plastic bottles after being purchased and used by the consumer 3. To make the plastic bottle producing companies pay plastic taxes for the recycling and deposit-system of the plastic bottles (under the principle that the polluter should pay)
annex: Problem: What is the problem with plastics? When plastics are not recycled or collected, they can end up in landfills or waterways. The Great Pacific Garbage Patch, for example, is an island of floating plastic in the Pacific Ocean between California and Hawaii. With 80.000 tons of plastic, it is currently 3 times the size of France and accumulating rapidly. When the tidal waves break the plastics into smaller pieces overtime, animals like fish eat it, which is how microplastics end up on our plates. Scientific studies estimate that any person ingests on average 5 grams worth of microplastics a week (the equivalent of a credit card) through food consumption. Recently microplastics were found in a human placenta. This shows that plastics do not only affect the natural environments and animals, but also humans. We need to address the plastic pollution problem at the source. Solution: What is our proposed solution? #Returntheplastics proposes deposit system to recycle bottles in supermarkets #Returntheplastics is an initiative with an innovative proposal: to recycle plastic bottles based on a 15 euro cents deposit fee for every plastic bottle purchase in the European Union. Once empty, the consumer can return the plastic bottle to a supermarket which has a reverse vending machine to collect bottles for recycling. When the consumer brings back the empty plastic bottle, the consumer receives the 15 euro cents deposit fee which can be spent again in the supermarket. On 3 July 2021 the EU Directive on single-use plastics entered into force, which bans the 10 most common single-use plastic items (such as plates, cutlery, straws) in all EU member states, through a law approved by the European Parliament. However, plastic bottles which are among the most commonly used plastic products (it is estimated that globally 1 million bottles a minute are bought) and take up to 500 years to decompose, are not included in the single-use plastics ban. Therefore, the #ReturnthePlastics European Citizen’s Initiative proposes an EU Directive for a deposit system to allow consumers to conveniently return their plastic bottles to the supermarkets where they were purchased, to close the loop on the materials used for producing the bottles. #ReturnthePlastics created a special logo that plastic PET-bottle producers can include on the label of the PET-bottles they produce. This logo indicates that a deposit of 15 euro cents will be paid with the purchase of the bottle by the consumer at the cashier. When scanning the barcode of the plastic bottle, the 15 euro cents deposit will automatically be added to the consumer’s bill, mentioning that this amount is the deposit fee for the plastic bottle purchase. Throughout the EU, there are many examples of effective recycling systems. In Germany there is a dual system to recycle plastic bottles, first through sorting waste and secondly through a deposit-system whereby consumers pay a deposit fee when purchasing plastic bottles in the supermarket and then getting a voucher to spend in the same supermarket when returning the bottle to the reverse vending machine at the entrance. In Rome, a metro ticket fee can be paid (partially) with plastic bottles through reverse vending machines. With #ReturnthePlastics we want to create a recycling system that can be implemented in supermarkets in every country as the start of a global solution to plastic pollution. Worldwide streets, landfills, oceans, forests, beaches are filled with plastic PET-bottles, which can take up to 450 years to decompose. This innovation will solve different issues all at once: the process of recycling requires less energy or raw materials than the production of entirely new bottles, plastic bottles will no longer be found as trash on the street but picked up instead and this system will create awareness about the environmental cost of the production of plastic on our planet. The goal of the is to have implemented the #ReturnthePlastics recycling system for plastic bottles in 5 EU member states by the Climate Conference COP26 from 1-12 November 2021 in Glasgow and later in all 26 EU member states. We hope to become a global movement of change for refusing, recycling and reducing plastic in a fight against plastic pollution.

title: Ensuring Common Commercial Policy conformity with EU Treaties and compliance with international law
objective: We seek to regulate commercial transactions with Occupant’s entities based or operating in occupied territories by withholding products originating from there from entering the EU market. The Commission, as Guardian of the Treaties, has to ensure consistency of Union’s policy and compliance with fundamental rights and international law in all areas of EU law, including CCP. It must propose legal acts based on the Common Commercial Policy to prevent EU legal entities from both importing products originating in illegal settlements in occupied territories and exporting to such territories, in order to preserve the integrity of the internal market and to not aid or assist the maintenance of such unlawful situations. The initiative thus invites the Commission to submit a proposal for a legal act under the Common Commercial Policy which is general in nature and does not target a specific country or territory.

               — Enact regulation to protect all life from radio frequency and microwave radiation *
               

               2. With 5G the amount of connected electronic devices, antennas and satellites will explode. Unsustainable energy consumption, radiation emissions, harmful mining and pollution will  follow, which will endanger biodiversity and natural habitats
               
               — Enact stronger regulation to protect the environment from all the impacts of 5G and digitalization*

annex: Enact regulation to protect all life from radio frequency and microwave radiation Hundreds of peer-reviewed scientific studies independent from industry including the most recent research prove radiofrequency electromagnetic fields (RF EMF) have harmful bioeffects at intensities millions of times lower than current limits. We demand the application of the precautionary principle to RF EMF in order to protect against risks to the environment and human health Ten proposals to implement in EU law 1. Enact RF EMF exposure limits based on all health and biological effects, not only those related to temperature, to protect humans – above all children, pregnant women, patients, the elderly, the infirm, electrohypersensitive people (EHS), those injured by this radiation and those using electromedical devices or implants; apply the precautionary principle 2. We demand limits are set to the MOST PROTECTIVE AMONG ALL scientific and empirical guidelines available, including • Council of Europe Resolution 1815 • Bioinitiative 2012 • Building biology evaluation guidelines • EUROPAEM EMF Guideline 2016 4. Ensure additional exposure guidelines are made by scientists with biomedical expertise and who are free from conflicts of interest: appoint a new panel or expand SCHEER’s activities to assess RF EMF’s bioactive parameters 5. Ensure the testing of wireless devices, antennas and their operation assesses all biologically active parameters of RF EMF 6. Replace wireless connections with cables. By 2025 they could account for 20% of worldwide electricity consumption Eight proposals to implement in EU law 11. Include "Waste from Electrical and Electronical Equipment" (WEEE), other waste products, and the environmental impacts of mining for rare earth minerals and metals used in electronical equipment in the “Zero pollution action plan” 14. Update Ecodesign Directive from 2009 setting tight limits to resource and energy waste of all connected devices including antennas and satellites 15. Recognize all biologically harmful parameters of RF EMF as a pollutant. Include them in all relevant EU Policies and Directives 16. It is also extremely concerning that 70% of investment in 5G is in surveillance systems, including facial recognition cameras and drones. Five proposals to implement in EU law 19. Launch an impact assessment of the effects of 5G, including connected objects and bodies, on personal data protection and evaluate compliance against current data protection laws 20. Ensure the European Data Protection Board fight actively and independently against discrimination and digital rights violations 22. Require each citizen’s explicit consent in order to subject their data to any automated procedure 23. Organize public debates on whether or to what extent to authorise digital innovations, led by scientists with biomedical expertise and who are free from conflicts of interest: appoint a new ethics committee or expand EGE's activities * Study our more detailed annex in the additional information

title: Call to Action – Environmental protection in all policies
objective:
The Commission has to safeguard and improve Europeans' quality of life, whilst protecting other species and the natural environment as a whole. Thereby, the Commission must propose a legal act- recommendation that leads to a better understanding and compliance with environmental protection measures in  EU Member States.
               

               The objective of the initiative is for the Commission to propose a legal act that would assure Europeans that their national authorities are taking into account environmental considerations when introducing new or amending existing policies.
annex: The last five years were the warmest in recorded history. The average global temperature last year was 0.6 ° C above the thirty-year average. Scientists' reports show that Eastern and Southern Europe are among those regions (along with Alaska, the Arctic, South Africa and Australia) that are most exposed to global warming. In 2021, the latest Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) report showed, that governmets are lacking in implementation of measures to protect the Environment and that we are coming to the point of irreversibility. Lack of implementation of measures is also at the centre of the 7th Environmental Report. Climate change is happening faster and faster, and its impacts will increase. This will change climate and environmental patterns in the future by further rising temperatures, extending warm and growing seasons in areas of greater latitude, lead to changes in rainfall patterns, as well as more frequent droughts and heat waves, stronger and more frequent tropical cyclones and other weather extremes. On 28 January 2019, the European Parliament declared an extreme climate conditions. When considering two resolutions, the European Parliament set out the European Commission's obligation to set out an action plan in line with the commitment to limit global warming to less than 1.5 ° C. In so doing, the EU will have to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 55% by 2030 and become climate neutral by 2050. Our ecosystems are undoubtedly threatened by both climate change and unsustainable production and distribution of goods and services. As a result, we have essentially been in an environmental crisis for several decades, which has only been intensifying in recent years. We are losing forests and biodevelopment faster than ever before, glaciers are shrinking, amount of waste is increasing, water sources are put under stress, and marine life is deteriorating. With the industrial revolution, the social understanding of nature and the environment became entirely egocentric, with the consumer society, with its flourishing in recent decades, thoroughly undermining the foundations of environmental stability. The problem has grown from a regional to a global level. Mankind today is facing not only a decline in environmental quality standards, but also a fundamental issue of survival. We are facing increasing environmental challenges, with climate change representing only the tip of the iceberg. Many other complex environmental problems, including the loss of forests and biodiversity, accumulation of waste, soil poisoning and endangering our greatest asset – drinking water are also becoming more prevalent. We are in an environmental crisis that, especially among young people, has given a sense of helplessness, yet at the same time has led to an increase in interest in shaping future policies. As first, we need to protect our forests as lungs of Europe.

title: Green VAT - An EU Green VAT to stimulate sustainable and eco-friendly products and services
objective: Reducing the VAT rate for green products and services
annex: It is the 21st century, "the digital decade" according to the President of the European Commission. These days, almost anything is possible online. All it takes is just one click to buy shoes from Italy or superfruits from South America. E-commerce is booming, but this also has its downsides. Climate change is omnipresent, and the question of what each individual can do to support climate protection is becoming more and more prominent in the minds of Europe's citizens. For consumers, it is difficult to determine whether the products they buy have been produced using eco-friendly or sustainable methods. Although the consumer has little influence over this process, the legislators do. In every country of the European Union, B2C merchants are required to pay VAT to the state. In turn, they add the amount to be paid to the purchase price of the goods that customers buy. Thus, the amount of VAT as a component of the price has an influence on the end consumer's purchasing decisions. Every Member State of the European Union could actively support climate and environmental protection by reducing the VAT rate for "green" products. In addition, incentives would be created for businesses to produce in a resource and environmentally-friendly way and to invest in research. A win-win situation for everyone involved – especially for our future and the protection of our planet. With our Green VAT legislative initiative we are appealing to the European Commission to initiate tax reductions for ecological, sustainably-produced and environmentally-friendly products in Europe. VAT is available to every government in the European Union as a fiscal policy tool. A corresponding EU requirement would have to be implemented by all EU Member States. The Commission could use the flexibilization of VAT rates decided by the ECOFIN Council in the summer as a basis for Green VAT. Accordingly, each product can be assigned an individual VAT rate ranging from 5 to 25%. The European Union has some 450 million inhabitants. Climate change affects everyone. Green VAT could be a practicable and effective means to make a subtle offer to the so-called throwaway society – especially in times of rapid consumption: People can support climate protection through their own consumer behavior.

title: Win It On The Pitch
objective:
PROTECT CLUBS, COMMUNITIES, AND COMPETITIONS
               
               Council recommendation on protecting the model of sport in Europe based on values, solidarity, sustainability, and open competitions
               

               The European model of sport is based on popular principles such as sporting merit, promotion and relegation, qualification to Europe via domestic success, and financial solidarity. This model and its principles must be further protected at the EU-level to prevent any more super league style breakaway attempts and protect our clubs, communities and competitions from hostile and reckless corporate and financial prospecting into European sport by private organisations and sovereign wealth funds.
               

               Sport is an integral part of the fabric of European society and culture that must be protected and promoted for the benefit of all.
               

               We are calling on the Council to adopt a Recommendation providing an EU framework and guidelines for member state action to:
               

               • Protec
annex: BACKGROUND The super league fiasco proved that European sport is on the brink of catastrophe. Decades of mismanagement has left countless clubs and competitions vulnerable to predatory takeovers by private individuals and groups whose only aim is to make money. Enough is enough. Sport is a social good that belongs to everyone—not just the wealthy and the elite. Now more than ever, it is crucial that the institutions of the European Union, Member States, and politicians work with fans and concerned citizens to safeguard football and other sports across the continent. OBJECTIVES This means turning the post-super league outpouring of indignation, solidarity, and common purpose into a clear, practical, and long-term plan of action at the European level. Such a plan must be devised and implemented swiftly to deter further breakaway attempts, as well as continued toxic investment in and asset stripping of clubs and communities. Failure to do so will no doubt embolden the usual suspects. Indeed, it will not be long until they renew their efforts to replace the European model of sport with a cartel model that preserves and promotes their own narrow competitive and economic interests at the expense of the wider game and European society. The basis for action, and for policy, is, thankfully, provided by EU treaties, which direct and empower the Council and Commission to defend a values-driven, socially embedded, and open vision of European sport: “Union action shall be aimed at developing the European dimension in sport, by promoting fairness and openness in sporting competitions.” It is time to live up to that vision—it is time to ensure that everybody must Win It On The Pitch: protect European sport and recognise its contribution to European society.

title: Fur Free Europe
objective:
Fur farming is inherently cruel and it is widely rejected by EU citizens.
               

               It is impossible to improve the welfare of animals on fur farms. Whilst no animals should live in a caged environment, the keeping of inherently wild species in cages can only be defined as abject cruelty.
               

               The keeping and killing of animals solely for the purpose of fur production is ethically unacceptable.
               

               Numerous outbreaks of SARS-CoV-2 on mink farms have evidenced the veterinary-public health risks associated with the production of fur.
               

               The existence of production bans in some Member States has a distorting impact on the market for the supply of farmed fur products. title: Good Clothes, Fair Pay
annex: This ECI calls on the Commission to propose targeted due diligence legislation to ensure workers’ human right to a living wage is protected across the supply chains of garment, textile, leather and footwear companies. In many EU Member States in which the garment sector is a large employer, the statutory minimum wage only accounts for a small percentage of a living wage. In the major garment-producing countries outside the EU the statutory minimum wage is on average, less than 50% of what is needed to finance a basic decent life. Long-standing economic hardship faced by workers has been exacerbated by an increase in harmful commercial practices and wage theft during the COVID-19 crisis. Workers’ wages in the garment industry decreased by more than 20% between March and August 2020. The ILO has expressed particular concerns regarding the disproportionate gender-specific impacts of the pandemic. The Universal Declaration of Human Rights and Article 7 of the International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights enshrine the right to a remuneration providing all workers, at a minimum, with a decent living for themselves and their families. Addressing living wages would result in EU garment and footwear consumption contributing to the achievement of the goals of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development, namely the eradication of poverty, gender equality, decent work and sustainable production and consumption. Furthermore, addressing low wages tackles one of the key drivers of child labour. This is in line with the Commission’s commitment towards the elimination of child labour, which the EC has emphasised needs to be kept at the forefront of all relevant policy areas. Legislation in this field should complement the Directive on Corporate Sustainable Due Diligence and the Adequate Minimum Wage Directive. It shall require undertakings to identify, prevent, mitigate and remedy adverse impacts on living wages, freedom of association and the right to collective bargaining in the regions they source from, taking account of the right to equal pay for equal work. The undertakings shall be required to track and communicate the progress of the mitigating measures taken within the due diligence process, including through a publicly available time-bound and target-bound plan, assessed on a yearly basis. All relevant stakeholders shall be fully involved in the design and implementation of the undertakings’ due diligence processes. The Commission may recommend appropriate and legitimate methodologies for the determination of living wages. Such living wage benchmarks may likewise be taken into account for wage negotiations in the sector. Undertakings should encourage as much as possible collective bargaining agreements at supplier level to increase wages. In addition, the legislation shall build on the Directive on unfair trading practices in the agri-food sector. As evidenced by the ILO,  the garment and footwear sector is one of the sectors most affected by unfair trading practices. Given fears that buyers may end  business relationships if suppliers do not accept their conditions, many suppliers do not have sufficient bargaining power to defend themselves against unfair practices, including unfair pricing. The prohibition of unfair trading practices is necessary, particularly in order to protect workers which eventually have to bear the consequences of these unfair trading practices. To ensure accountability, it is also necessary to improve transparency in the sector. Undertakings shall make publicly available an annual report on the strategy and implementation of their obligations on their websites. Furthermore, legislation shall provide an obligation for undertakings to publish certain production information from their supply chains and a right to information for consumers regarding actual and potential adverse impacts related to wages and precarious contracting arrangements. In addition, the legislation shall address the high mobility of demand, which is one of the key structural challenges in the garment and footwear sector. As if it were nothing more than a commodity, purchasers of footwear and garment can move from one production zone to another to obtain the lowest labour costs. Consequently, national governments cannot increase their minimum wage levels without risking losing business to countries with lower wage levels. In order to reverse this race to the bottom, undertakings shall be subject to enhanced scrutiny as long as they supply goods from high-risk low-wage countries where the minimum statutory wage level in the sector is below the wage risk point and freedom of association and collective bargaining are not guaranteed. The Commission has applied a similar approach in its proposal for a Regulation on deforestation-free products. These structural challenges pinpoint the urgent need for EU intervention. Some undertakings have made commitments to improve wages, but systemic progress in the sector is still timid. In an interconnected market, the ability of any single undertaking to bring about systemic change is limited. The EU is a key market and, as such, has considerable leverage to address the challenges of poverty wages in global supply chains.

title: Protect the EU’s Rural Heritage, Food Security and Supply
objective:
PROTECT AND PROMOTE THE EU’S RURAL AREAS AND FOOD SECURITY.
               




                Europe’s rural regions are losing their heritage, industries, populations, and values – threatening food security and supply across the EU. To preserve what makes these regions unique for future generations and ensure the longevity of the EU’s food-producing communities, we need a renewed EU commitment to the promotion of regional heritage, rural sustainable growth and rising living standards.
               



                This European Citizens Initiative asks the EU to modernise its rural commitments to take into consideration the need for greater food security, supply of agricultural materials and protection for the rural way of life – its people, their values and livelihoods.
annex: The EU must respect its rural communities, their heritage, and values. Europe has a proud tradition of supporting its agricultural and rural-based communities and their way of life. And yet, our rural sectors and those that work them face increasing pressure and diminishing incentives to continue, which, if not addressed, will lead to the extinction of some of Europe’s most foundational communities and values. The textiles industry is a prime example, which has become centred around fast fashion rather than environmentally sustainable slow and natural fibre-based fashion. We wish for the EU to promote and support environmentally sustainable rural production of goods, food and other agricultural outputs across the Member States. As such, this Citizens’ Initiative aims, within the competencies conferred to the EU by the Treaties: -   We request the EU Commission to create a proposal to strengthen and preserve regional heritages and industries throughout the EU. The proposal must boost rural growth and promote rural job practices and activities such as agriculture (family to large-scale), gamekeeping, horticulture and natural fibre production in the textile industry (wool, silk, fur and cotton) that are at the heart of rural communities. It is necessary for the proposal to consider and respect the traditional crafting industries that rely on rurally sourced materials and smaller fringe businesses that service large-scale farms. The proposal must recognise food security and supply (fertiliser, biogas materials etc.) and the importance of maintaining a robust regional food supply in Europe. -   Promote investment and rising living standards in rural communities by developing regional heritage focused tourism, education and industry across the EU, with respect to sustainable production. -   While welcoming the EU’s Green initiatives, the Commission must consult with local and rural representatives on the details of implementation. We, EU citizens, invite the Commission to introduce by law, throughout the Union, the: -   The inclusion of rural heritage promotion and recognition of food security/supply in the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development, providing investment and legislative protection for traditional practices. This would include updating Rural Development Regulation (EU) No 1305/2013 or its successor to have a larger emphasis on the promotion and investment in local cultural heritage, where it can demonstrate increased use of sustainable production and protection of the EU’s food security. -   The Long-term Vision for the EU’s Rural Areas up to 2040, Rural Pact and EU Rural Action Plan should increase their scope to include investment and legislative protection for rural heritage where it can demonstrate increased use of sustainable production and promotion of EU food security and supply.

title: Focus on Specific Learning Disabilities on EU Level
objective:
This Initiative aims to facilitate the access to education of people with specific learning disabilities (i.e. dyslexia, dyscalculia, dysgraphia). Students with such disabilities face struggles in pursuing their education due to lack of knowledge about the topic, absence of adequate study materials, and unfair exam conditions.
               
               Although the Member States have addressed the issue individually, the discrepancies in  the definitions of learning disabilities, the distinct methods of detection and assistance opens a gap between the countries. Hence, students may be treated differently in other Member States which could hinder their right of free movement as granted by the Treaties, resulting in repercussions on their education and integration into society.
               
               Hereby, we request the Commission to present a proposal for a Council recommendation pursuant to Article 165(4), second indent, TFEU with common guidelines to the national governments on how to detect and address learning disabilities. A better integration of people with learn
annex: Nowadays, the European Union is facing multiple issues of inclusivity, as shown in the EU disabilities strategy (2021 - 2027). In order to ensure that every student, diagnosed with a form of a specific learning disability in the EU, is granted the compensatory method that they need, it is important that the Commission encourages the Member States to work together. This initiative aims to address specific learning disabilities such as dyslexia, dyscalculia, disprassia, disortografia though, we see the possibility of enlarging the scope. We consider this proposal as a major step towards tackling the inclusivity issues highlighted in the EU disability strategy. With this initiative, we ask the Commission to present a proposal for a Council recommendation pursuant to art 165(4), second indent, TFEU. Moreover, research has proven that not integrating people with specific learning disabilities in schools can have repercussions on both their individual development and on their position in society. If dyslexia is not addressed properly, it can cause anxiety, anger issues and depression. It can also have a negative effect on people’s social and communication skills, as well as in their relationships with their parents and siblings (International Dyslexia Association, 2022). Another study reveals that dyslexic people who have failed in their studies are more likely to pursue criminal activities (Macdonald, 2012). However, if students struggling with this kind of disabilities are helped from an early stage both in the family and in school, it is more likely that they develop an “emotional well-being” (International Dyslexia Association, 2022). Although these articles focus on dyslexia, the most known form of a specific learning disability, we can assume that all individuals who struggle with a specific learning disability are at risk to the above-mentioned negative consequences. International Dyslexia Association states that a clear understanding of the issues reduces the difficulties for a person with specific learning disabilities to integrate into society. Therefore, this initiative has three key points. First, it can highlight  the globality of the issue and the need to tackle it on a European level.  For instance, it is difficult to estimate exactly how many people have specific learning disabilities for a number of reasons. To begin with, each Member State uses a different medical definition and includes a different set of disabilities when creating their legislations on the matter. (A comparative study about different legal definitions in some EU countries is attached to this Annex.) Furthermore, not all people with learning disabilities get diagnosed or seek support. When it actually comes to detection, the Member States delegate the responsibility to different specialists: neurologists, psychologists, specifically trained teachers, etc. Hence, the detection methods also vary from simple tests to detailed neurological analyses. This initiative aims to ameliorate these discrepancies. Second, with its team of experts and broader perspective of the Member States’ legislations, the Commission can significantly contribute to the research on specific learning disabilities. This research should focus on finding a European-wide definition of learning disabilities and establishing compensatory measures. A common definition would secure the protection of students with specific learning disabilities' rights when moving to study in another Member State. Although disabilities affect students differently, and it is best that the compensatory measures are tailor made according to the individual’s necessities, there are already some practices that could be commonly applied. For example, slight adjustments in the grading system, granting more time during exams and allowing the use of a computer can already significantly improve  the student’s potential. Third, it can stress the importance of using new technologies in facilitating the learning process for students with learning disabilities. One of the most useful compensatory methods so far is the computer which provides students with reading aloud softwares, orthographic correctors, etc. These two options can significantly improve the comprehension and writing skills of people with dyslexia and dysgraphia. Computers can also secure a fairer treatment during exams and, thus, help students reveal their full potential. Since some poorer European regions do not invest in bringing new technologies to the classrooms, the EU can bring the national governments’ attention to the issue and to the potential of the newest technologies. Finally, good news, thanks to the VEGANUARY initiative at least 10 times the same number of participants take part in VEGANUARY without registering, so the results obtained should be multiplied by 10, making it clear what veganism is doing for the planet. Based on the results obtained by encouraging the consumption of plant-based food, as demonstrated in VEGANUARY 2022, the EU Citizens' Initiative for VEGAN MEAL asks for the introduction of the vegan alternative in the sale of food and beverages to the public in Europe by law with the hope that the participation of European citizens leads to the approval of an EU law with great benefits for the planet, i.e. in mitigation of the climate crisis, extinction of wild species, deforestation, better use of land, defense of marine life, food waste and malnutrition. We urgently need action rather than empty words. We know what needs to be done. What is missing is the political will to take a new approach and a real commitment. Be vegan to defend nature. A well-planned vegan diet is suitable for all stages of life, even in childhood, and satisfies the need for all nutrients: this is officially stated in an article published recently in the Journal of the Academy of Nutrition and Dietetics. The EU Citizens' Initiative for VEGAN MEAL asks for a law to make easier access to the vegan alternative, i.e. that the vegan alternative has to be guaranteed in the sale of food and drinks to the public, with the awareness of the change in society, economy, and the environment that we generate when we choose vegan food. Aspects that we believe are positive, non-discriminatory, and non-harmful, in line with the transition to a more eco-sustainable diet.

title: European Day of "Whatever it Takes"
objective:
Plea for the institutionalization of a European Day of Whatever it Takes
               

               An appeal to the EU Commission for the institutionalization of the European Day of “Whatever it Takes”- 26.07.2012 to mark in history the institutional wisdom and game-changing capacity of the European Institutions during the Great Recession. An inspiring chapter of EU’s functional resiliency and core capabilities for institutions, nations and societies to drive progress while sailing times of multiple-crisis management.
annex: This Initiative is a brief statement of love for Europe, a gesture of positivity in times of easy hate and a public appeal to bring voices together around EU institutions and their values against a landscape of societal polarization, geopolitical conflict and economic instability. This initiative is a collective statement of faith in Europe and confidence in its adaptive capacity to navigate through present and future storms, towards an “ever-closer union among the peoples of Europe”. Ten years after Draghi’s “three magic words” that changed the course of a crisis that left the Eurozone on the brink of collapse, Europe is once again sailing through uncharted waters that require extraordinary capacity of collective action. While leaving behind a pandemic and facing an unprovoked war at home, Europe is dealing with unprecedented inflationary pressures threatening the Eurozone in an asymmetric way, with the financial markets once again, challenging the integrity of the EMU while testing the policy menu of the ECB. Ten years ago, ECB shifted its profile of action within the limitations of TFEU and took the front of EU’s collective response against the sharpest recession affecting postwar Europe. When the liquidity crunch degenerated into a solvency shock and national governments turned their efforts to save their banking systems and budgetary equilibria, ECB decisively broke the deadly spiral of negative market sentiment over sovereign debts and national economies. The real purpose of this initiative is to set in stone this inspiring chapter in EU history as a landmark of our collective capacity to overcome common obstacles to our development and build back better as a democratic block of nations jointly striving for progress. Today, it’s fairly indisputable how instrumental Mr. Draghi’s leadership was in readapting the algorithms of the ECB - a heart-institution of the EMU - making it a better-equipped central bank in support of Eurozone economies. The “three magic words”, part of a non- standard speech in London (2012, July), marked day one of a new monetary era with an immediate stabilizing effect on financial markets. They also represented the beginning of the end of the sovereign debt crisis. They not only resulted in the salvation of the Eurozone but they also loosened the “deadly embrace” between banks and sovereign economies facing simultaneous solvency and liquidity shocks. PROPOSAL This Citizens' Initiative aims to mobilize EU voices around the ideal of a wider recognition of our collective wins and the proven capacity to overcome major obstacles. The strength of a symbolic representation by celebrating a “Whatever it Takes” Day depends on the institutional solemnity bestowed upon it and ultimately, on its cultural alignment with EU fundamental values. Aligned with the EU founding fathers, statesmen of dialogue who lived through two world wars and experienced bridging cultural differences based on a common search for peace and prosperity, we propose to carve into EU contemporary lifeline a “WiT Day” to elevate the intemporal guiding principles driving integration. The "whatever it takes" moment should be translated into our collective culture of action. It symbolizes the zero hour of a historical change of course during the Great Recession that saved the Euro and changed ECB for the better. It represents the turning point for European economies and macroeconomic recovery. This titanic struggle against the crisis and the complex task of changing ECB commands in the middle of a financial shock must inspire future institutional endeavors, in the name of EU’s collective progress. Our proposal to celebrate a “Whatever it Takes Day” is a symbolic act of pan-Europeanism and a lever to encourage our public institutions to continuously adapt, keeping pace with societal transformations and poised to shape the future. In rough times of supply chains disruptions, rising inflation and price instability across all Europe, the monetary policy system is back on top of political agendas. Fortunately, however, ECB is now much better equipped to respond quickly to global economic circumstances. It is our collective duty to celebrate a European Day of “Whatever it Takes” embracing an official and solemn effort to historicize the collective achievements of Europe. Marking this day in the timeline of the European construction is to commemorate the strength of our mutual beliefs, recognizing the functional wisdom of our institutions that work every day to bring nations and people together during divisive times. In essence, this manifesto offers three key messages in support of our plea for a European Day of “Whatever it Takes”: A) To set in stone one of the most critical efforts to save the Euro, as an act of recognition of the EU institutional wisdom and resilience during the Great Recession that severely threatened Eurozone and national economies; B)To bring EU voices together and celebrate the European values of democracy, cultural diversity, peace and human rights, in times of easy scorn, societal extremism, Euro-skepticism and populism rising throughout Europe; C) To shed light on the adaptive power and crisis-solving capabilities that European institutions need to maintain to drive progress and face what lies ahead. A “WiT” day is a direct appeal to the reformist capacity and transformative muscle the EU needs to preserve.

title: Article 4: Stop torture and inhuman treatment at Europe’s borders
objective: In the context of the EU’s powers in the area of justice, freedom and security – as set out in Article 78 TFEU on policies relating to border checks, asylum and immigration – we call for appropriate regulations to ensure that Article 4 of the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights is applied effectively and that the use of violence, torture and inhuman and degrading treatment is banned at EU borders and in non-EU countries which the European institutions or one or more Member States have concluded agreements with restricting the entry of migrants or asylum seekers into Europe, as well in the Member States themselves in managing reception, with penalties imposed for non-compliance with the obligations laid down.
annex: Article 4 of the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights states: ‘No one shall be subjected to torture or to inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment.’ In recent years, increasing violence has been perpetrated against migrants, which is a stain on our European conscience and contrasts starkly with the EU’s fundamental principles. Reports by organisations such as UNHCR, Amnesty International and Human Rights Watch, investigations by journalists and numerous testimonies from victims reveal torture, rape and threats in detention centres in Libya, a country which Italy has concluded departure control agreements with. Extremely poor conditions are reported in camps in Greece and Bosnia, where overcrowding and lack of hygiene and care endanger the lives of the most vulnerable. Disproportionate use of force and repeated episodes of violence by Croatian police against asylum seekers are reported at the border with Serbia and Bosnia. Migrants have been illegally detained in various EU countries and countries funded by the EU, violent pushbacks have taken place all along Europe’s borders and in practice the right to apply for asylum has been suspended. The ECI urges the EU to use its powers in the area of justice, freedom and security – set out in Article 78 TFEU on policies relating to border checks, asylum and immigration – to put an end to these frequent and repeated violations of a fundamental EU principle, as reflected in Article 4 of the Charter, and to protect migrants and asylum seekers: 1- on entry into the common European area, by regulating border checks and imposing penalties on countries that openly violate the ban on the use of violence, torture and inhuman and degrading treatment; 2- in non-EU countries, in the context of operations to ‘externalise EU borders’, by imposing penalties on Member States which conclude agreements that do not provide for the monitoring of compliance with Article 4; 3- in setting reception standards for the entire period of residence in the EU, by imposing penalties on countries whose authorities and/or law enforcement agencies infringe the rights of migrants or asylum seekers.

title: Ensuring a dignified reception of migrants in Europe
objective:
The treatment of migrants in the European Union (EU) too often fails to respect the principles of human dignity, a fundamental value of the Union.
               

                The main reason, in our view, is the persistent inadequacy of European rules and the lack of solidarity between Member States.
               

                As the Union is "an area of freedom, security and justice with respect for fundamental rights",
                
                 we, European citizens, ask the EU
                 
                  to ensure a dignified reception of migrants, as soon as they enter the territory
                 

                , compatible with the fundamental rights recognized to every human being by the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights and international law.
               

                In order to contribute to this, we call, in the framework of the development of a common asylum policy, for the adoption of regulations to:
               

                1- Introduce a new mechanism for the distribution of asylum seekers in the EU, based on their free wil
annex: The treatment of migrants in the European Union too often does not respect the principles of human dignity, a fundamental value of the Union (Art.2 TEU). The EU Charter of Fundamental Rights states in its Article 1: "Human dignity is inviolable. It must be respected and protected". It also recognizes that every human being has the right to respect for fundamental rights such as the right to health, to social assistance and to housing, the right to education and the right to work. We therefore consider that all migrants have the right to human dignity and respect for fundamental rights. Despite the European Commission's constant desire to improve a dysfunctional asylum and migration regime, many legislative and policy changes remain to be adopted at both EU and national levels to ensure dignified treatment of all migrants. We believe that the Union, for its part, can advance respect for dignity in Europe by revising the asylum rules of the Dublin Regulation (I) and by making binding in the States reception standards that guarantee asylum seekers dignified living conditions that are comparable in all Member States (II). Thus, while respecting the Union's competences, our proposals for changes to secondary legislation are part of the development of a common asylum policy (Article 78§2) I. Establish a new mechanism for the distribution of asylum seekers in the EU The Dublin Regulation, which determines which European state is responsible for an asylum application, has created a counter-productive mechanism, feeding national egoisms, by which Europe condemns to wandering an increasing proportion of those who come to seek refuge. It de facto places the bulk of the responsibility for asylum demand on a few states. In 2020, almost 80% of first asylum applications were made in Greece, Italy and Spain. This imbalance leads to the persistence of undignified situations: overcrowded camps on the Greek islands or summary deportations contrary to international law at the EU's borders. In addition, almost 1 in 4 asylum seekers make their application in a state other than the one designated as responsible for the investigation. Transfers to the country of arrival remain marginal, particularly from Germany and France, which in 2019 received almost 68% of the EU's “dublined”. Thus, for a period of up to 18 months, they are condemned to wander and live in great precariousness, rarely benefiting from assistance or accommodation. We call for the adoption of a regulation which, revising Regulation 2013/604 "Dublin III", balances the sharing of reception in the EU, by: - a new allocation mechanism taking into account the aspirations of asylum seekers as a new criterion - and a binding solidarity (relocation) mechanism between Member States to correct disproportionate allocations. II. Make binding in the Member States reception standards that guarantee asylum seekers dignified living conditions that are comparable throughout the Union Reception conditions for asylum seekers differ greatly from one country to another and some have been found to be contrary to respect for human dignity and the prohibition of inhuman and degrading treatment by the European courts (CJEU, C-179/11; ECHR, N.H. and others v. France - Judgment 2.7.2020) Acknowledging these" significant gaps", the European Commission, in its 2016 proposal for a recast of the Reception Conditions Directive, recalled the need for "uniform conditions" that are sufficient "to ensure a dignified standard of living and comparable living conditions in all Member States". We consider that disparities between Member States will remain if these proposed provisions do not become binding and directly applicable in the Member States. We call for the adoption of a regulation (repealing Directive 2013/33/EU) on reception conditions for asylum seekers in the EU, guaranteeing them a dignified standard of living and comparable living conditions in all Member States, requiring Member States: - to fully respect fundamental rights and general principles of Union law, as well as the requirements of international law; - ensure that asylum seekers are provided with material reception conditions from the moment of their entry into the territory of the Union which comply a minima with the operational standards and indicators for material reception conditions developed at EU level by the European Asylum and Migration Office (EASO), in terms of "accommodation, food, clothing and non-food items, daily allowance, information and counselling and health care"; - guarantee the rights of the child as they result from the Charter of Fundamental Rights and the International Convention on the Rights of the Child, in particular to ensure the schooling and education of minors, without condition of residence in the Member State in which the applicant is required to be present, as long as an expulsion order is not enforced against them; - to facilitate access to employment. Applicants, regardless of the expected outcome of their application, should be allowed to work as soon as possible, within 6 months, even if their application is in process; - have emergency reception plans developed and monitored in partnership with local and regional actors, such as NGOs and local authorities.

title: End The Horse Slaughter Age
objective:
The
                
                 European Citizens’ Initiative End The Horse Slaughter Age
                
                asks for a law to ban the slaughter of horses, including in the ban also their breeding and their export for the production of fur, leather, meat or for the manufacture of medicines or other substances.
               

                The
                
                 European Citizens’ Initiative End The Horse Slaughter Age
                
                asks also for a law to stop long-distance transportation of horses across Europe for slaughter and a regulation to protect horse from being compelled to do excess work or hard training.
annex: The European Citizens’ Initiative End The Horse Slaughter Age asks to the European Commission to enact a law to ban horse slaughter in Europe. The European Citizens’ Initiative End The Horse Slaughter Age asks for a law to ban the slaughter of horses and all other equines, including in the ban also their breeding and their export for the production of fur, leather, meat or for the manufacture of medicines or other substances, bringing horses into line with legislation regarding dogs and cats. The European Citizens’ Initiative End The Horse Slaughter Age asks also for a law to stop long-distance transportation of horses across Europe for slaughter and a regulation to protect horse from being compelled to do excess work or hard training. The European Citizens’ Initiative End The Horse Slaughter Age wants to let people know what really happens to horses in slaughterhouses by looking the truth in the face and put an end forever to the slaughter of horses that unjustly die in atrocious suffering.
